official-title.#text: Impeaching Eric H. Holder, Jr., Attorney General of the United States, for high crimes and misdemeanors.

cosponsor.#tail: ) submitted the following resolution; which was referred to the

text.#text: That Eric H. Holder, Jr., Attorney General of the United States, is impeached for high crimes and misdemeanors, and that the following articles of impeachment be exhibited to the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: in the name of itself and all of the people of the United States of America, against Eric H. Holder, Jr., Attorney General of the United States, in maintenance and support of its impeachment against him for high crimes and misdemeanors.
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text: House of Representatives of the United States of America

text.#text: Articles of impeachment exhibited by the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: on October 12, 2011, in connection with a legitimate Congressional investigation into Operation Fast and Furious by the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, and Firearms that put thousands of illegally purchased weapons into the hands of cartel leaders, ultimately resulting in the death of U.S. Border Patrol Agent Brian Terry on December 14, 2010.
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text: House Committee on Oversight and Government Reform

text.#text: Eric H. Holder, Jr., while Attorney General of the United States, engaged in a pattern of conduct incompatible with the trust and confidence placed in him in that position by refusing to comply with a subpoena issued by the

Wherefore, Eric H. Holder, Jr., Attorney General of the United States, is guilty of high crimes and misdemeanors and should be removed from office and disqualified to hold and enjoy any office of honor, trust, or profit under the United States.

Eric H. Holder, Jr., while Attorney General of the United States, and responsible for enforcing the laws of the United States regardless of personal bias, failed to enforce multiple laws, including the

Wherefore, Eric H. Holder, Jr., Attorney General of the United States, is guilty of high crimes and misdemeanors and should be removed from office and disqualified to hold and enjoy any office of honor, trust, or profit under the United States.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: scandal of unauthorized disclosure of tax records belonging to political donors.

text.#text: Eric H. Holder, Jr., while Attorney General of the United States, has failed his oath of office by refusing to prosecute individuals involved in the

Wherefore, Eric H. Holder, Jr., Attorney General of the United States, is guilty of high crimes and misdemeanors and should be removed from office and disqualified to hold and enjoy any office of honor, trust, or profit under the United States.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: on May 15, 2013, that he was neither involved in nor had heard of a potential prosecution of the press. However three days later, the
released documents naming journalist James Rosen as a co-conspirator in an alleged violation of the
. Eric H. Holder, Jr., Attorney General of the United States, confirmed to the
in a letter dated June 19, 2013, that he approved of a search warrant on James Rosen.

Wherefore, Eric H. Holder, Jr., Attorney General of the United States, is guilty of high crimes and misdemeanors and should be removed from office and disqualified to hold and enjoy any office of honor, trust, or profit under the United States.
